Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Situation2: They organize an intensive workshop for community leaders to deeply understand and apply complex theological concepts.
Story: The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my passenger anxiously checking his watch in the back seat. He’d pleaded with me to get him to the airport on time—his flight was the only one out before the storm shut everything down. As a taxi driver, I knew my job was to get him there safely and quickly, but the roads were slick, and every instinct told me to slow down. My phone buzzed with a reminder: the workshop I’d spent weeks preparing for as a pastor was starting in less than an hour. Community leaders were counting on me to guide them through difficult theological questions, to be present and focused. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—one demanding I brave the storm for a stranger’s urgent need, the other calling me to shepherd my flock with wisdom and care. My heart pounded as I stared at the icy road ahead, torn between the expectations of those who needed me, and the fear of letting someone down, no matter which path I chose.
